Authors: Luiz Henrique Martins Fonseca, Lúcia G. Lohmann
Title:
Biogeography and evolution of Dolichandra (Bignonieae,
Bignoniaceae)
Keywords:
Neotropics  chloroplast DNA  comparative methods 
diversification  molecular phylogenetics  nuclear markers  phylogenetic
signal  punctuated evolution
Abstract:
The Neotropics includes the largest concentration of
species of vascular plants on Earth. Yet, information on the
evolutionary relationships of Neotropical organisms is still scarce and
little is still known about the factors that have shaped the diversity
currently encountered in this region. It is clear, however, that both
biotic interactions and abiotic aspects have played important roles for
species diversification in the region. This study focuses on
Dolichandra, a clade of Neotropical lianas that is broadly distributed
across different habitats and whose species present diverse pollination
and dispersal systems. We use sequences from two cpDNA markers (ndhF and
rpl32-trnL) and one nuclear gene (PepC) to infer the phylogenetic
relationships within Dolichandra (Bignonieae, Bignoniaceae) using
parsimony and bayesian approaches. We then use this phylogenetic
framework as basis to study the biogeographic history, reconstruct the
evolution of morphological characters, and test the impact of morphology
and environment on the evolutionary history of the genus. More
specifically, we: (i) time-calibrated the phylogeny of Dolichandra, (ii)
estimated the ancestral areas of the various lineages, (iii) estimated
the ancestral states of discrete and continuous morphological traits,
(iv) tested for phylogenetic signal in environmental and phenotypic
data, and (v) evaluated if morphological characters and/or niche
evolution are correlated with cladogenesis. All species of Dolichandra
emerged as monophyletic in all analyses; relationships among species are
generally well resolved, although poorly supported in some instances.
The genus is inferred to have originated at ca. 31 Mya possibly in the
Eastern portion of South America. Ancestral state reconstructions of
continuous and discrete floral characters inferred a mixed morphology as
the ancestral condition for the group. Phylogenetic signal differed
between perianth and sexual whorls and gradual evolution was recovered
for all traits, except style length and anther length. Environmental
variables showed no phylogenetic signal and a pattern of variation that
was not correlated with branch lengths, suggesting that environmental
transitions were concomitant with speciation. Dispersion is inferred to
represent the main driver of the differential distribution observed
among species in the genus. In addition, climatic preferences and floral
characters also seem to have been important reproductive barriers in
Dolichandra.
